runs.text: Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
changes a noun into an adjective, or describing word, and adding -l
makes an adjective into an adverb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
. List the words as students form them. Discuss their meanings and spellings.
Have students write -y and -ly multiple times as they say the sounds for each.
(Add words with skills your students need to review.)
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: Factories and Mass Production
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.

Model how to add suffixes -y and -ly to the following words: rain (y), clean (ly). Explain that -y makes an adjectivea word that describes a noun. Point out that -ly makes an adverba word that describes a verb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
Have students add -y and -ly to the following words to see how many words they can make: itch, storm, year, like. List the words as they form them. Discuss their meanings and spellings.
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.

. Thats the part we need to remember.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.

Model how to add suffixes -y and -ly to the following words: trick (y), rare (ly). Explain that -y makes an adjectivea word that describes a noun. Point out that -ly makes an adverba word that describes a verb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with -
. Then have them put a box around each word with -y.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
low, slow, snow, snowy, slowly (cumulative review)

Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. Explain that -y makes an adjectivea word that describes a noun. Point out that -ly makes an adverba word that describes a verb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.

Ask them to write on paper or a dry-erase board a sentence for each word.

Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out what each word was before adding a suffix to it.
Encourage students to look for words with suffixes -
while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.
Read Aloud: The History of Money
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words currency, withdraw, value, digital, and allows, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.

Model how to add suffixes -y and -ly to the following words: sweat (y), most (ly). Explain that -y makes an adjectivea word that describes a noun. Point out that -ly makes an adverba word that describes an adjective or verb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.

Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. Model how to add suffixes -y and -ly to the following words: rust (y), near (ly). Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud. Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: able, behind, carefully, common, easy, fact, remember, sure, vowel, whole

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., We are able to _____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.

Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. Explain that -y makes an adjectivea word that describes a noun. Point out that -ly makes an adverba word that describes an adjective or a verb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with -

friend, friends, friendly, unfriendly (transition to multisyllabic)

Read Aloud: A History of Child Workers in America
Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words environment, attitudes, rely,employed, restrict, and minimum, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.

Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. Explain that -y makes an adjectivea word that describes a noun. Point out that -ly makes an adverba word that describes an adjective or a verb. Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences.
Read Aloud: Ordinary People with Extraordinary Ideas
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words ordinary, secure, alternative, effective, and operate, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.

, or show the Phonics/Syllable Cards. Read each one and have students repeat. Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech.
, one at a time. Model how to read the new words formed. Explain that -
(ly). Guide students to read the words and use each one in a sentence to show how their meaning changes after adding the suffix.
This word describes a sound that is deep and quiet.
Add two letters to low to form an adverb.
Add one letter to lowly to form an adverb that means in a slow way.
Delete two letters from slowly to form a word that means the opposite of fast.
Change one letter in slow to form a word that means frozen ice falling from the sky.
Add one letter to snow to form a word that describes the weather when it snows.
Read, Build, Write: able, behind, carefully, common, easy, fact, remember, sure,
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
